columns.text:
In this exercise, we will see how to calculate the price of a bond with changing coupon payments.

We'll also look at the scenario when the bond pays no coupon payments at all.

Let's start by explaining what the bond price is and how it's calculated. Bond price is the present discounted value of all of it's future cash returns. The future cash returns of a bond usually consist of coupon payments and the selling price at maturity. Hence, the bond price can be described as the sum of the present values of all future coupon payments and the present value of the face value at maturity: $$\text{Bond Price} = \text{FCP} + \text{FVAM} \tag{1}$$ Where: FCP - Future Coupon Payments FVAM - Face Value At Maturity

Let's first calculate the current bond price for bond N. We are given the following information on bond N: 1. The face value is assumed at $20,000. 2. Considering that the time to maturity is 20 years, the number of compounding periods will be 40. This is because the bond pays out the coupons semiannually. 3. The annual yield to maturity is 5.4%. Divide 7% by 2 to get the semiannual yield to maturity of 2.7%

Recall that the present value of future coupon payments can be calculated as follows: $$\text{FCP} = \dfrac{\text{Coupon}_1}{(1+YTM)^1 } + \dfrac{\text{Coupon}_2}{(1+YTM)^2 } + \dots + \dfrac{\text{Coupon}_n}{(1 + YTM)^n} \tag{2}$$ Where: n - Total number of compounding periods YTM - Yield to maturity FCP - Future coupon payments

Consider that we have three different types of periods with varying coupon payments over the bond's life.

There will be 40 payments paid semiannually by the bond for 20 years.

For the first six years, the bond pays out $0. Hence, for the first 12 payments, the coupon payment is $0.

Then the bond pays out $900 for the eight years. Hence, for the following 16 payments (payments 12-28), the coupon payment is $900.

Finally, the bond will pay out $1,200 for the last six years. Thus, the last 12 payments will be $1,200 (payments 28-40)

Hence, the total value of future coupon payments will be the sum of future coupon payments for each period: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{FCP}_N
&=  \sum_{n=1}^{12}\dfrac{\$0}{(1+2.7\%)^n } + \sum_{n=12}^{28}\dfrac{\$900}{(1+2.7\%)^n }  +\sum_{n=28}^{40}\dfrac{\$1,300}{(1 + 2.7\%)^n}  \\[15pt]
&=\$0 + \$9,056.81177 + \$6,865.10634 \\[15pt]
&= \$15,921.91811
\end{aligned}$$

We can calculate the current value of the face value at maturity as follows: $$\text{Face Value At Maturit} = \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t} \tag{3}$$ Where: FV - Face Value YTM - Yield to maturity t - The number of compounding periods

The total number of compounding periods is 40. The yield to maturity is 2.7%. Face value is assumed at $20,000. By inputting these values into Eq.$(3)$, we get the following face value at maturity: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Face Value At Maturity}_N &= \frac{\$20,0000}{(1+ 2.7\%)^{40}}\\[15pt] &=\$6,889.88942 \end{aligned}$$

We can now input the resulting values into Eq.$(1)$ to calculate the bond price for bond N: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Bond Price}_N &= \$15,921.91811 + \$6,889.88942 \\[15pt] &= \$22,811.80753 \end{aligned}$$ *What characteristic distinguishes zero coupon bonds from regular coupon bonds?*
The most important characteristic of zero-coupon bonds is that they don't pay out coupon payments. Hence, the present value of the future coupon payments is: $$\text{FCP}_M = \$0$$

The total number of compounding periods is 40. The yield to maturity is 2.7%. Face value is assumed at $20,000. By inputting these values into Eq.$(3)$, we get the following face value at maturity for bond M: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Par Value At Maturity}_M &= \frac{\$20,0000}{(1+ 2.7\%)^{40}}\\[15pt] &=\$6,889.88942 \end{aligned}$$
We can now input the resulting values into Eq.$(1)$ to calculate the bond price for bond N: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Bond Price}_N &= \$0 + \$6,889.88942 \\[15pt] &= \$6,889.88942 \end{aligned}$$

Let's recap what we have learned in this exercise!

First, we explained what the bond price is, and we recalled how it is calculated.

Then we calculated the bond price of bond N, which has varying values of coupon payments. 

Finally, we calculated the bond price for a bond that pays out no coupons. Such a bond is called a zero-coupon bond.
